raw_text:
$1m payoff for former Shell boss
 
 Shell is to pay $1m (£522,000) to the ex-finance chief who stepped down from her post in April 2004 after the firm over-stated its reserves.
 
 Judy Boynton finally left the firm on 31 December, having spent the intervening time as a special advisor to chief executive Jeroen van der Veer. In January 2004, Shell told shocked investors that its reserves were 20% smaller than previously thought. Shell said the pay-off was in line with Ms Boynton's contract. She was leaving "by mutual agreement to pursue other career opportunities", the firm said in a statement. The severance package means she keeps long-term share options, but fails to collect on a 2003 incentive plan since the firm has failed to meet the targets included in it.
 
 The revelation that Shell had inflated its reserves led to the resignation of its chairman, Sir Phil Watts, and production chief Walter van der Vijver.
 
 An investigation commissioned by Shell found that Ms Boynton had to share responsibility for the company's behaviour. Despite receiving an email from Mr Van de Vijver which said the firm had "fooled" the market about its reserves, the investigation said, she did nothing to inquire further. In all, Shell restated its reserves four times during 2003. In September, it paid £82.7m in fines to regulators on both sides of the Atlantic for violating market rules in its reporting of its reserves.
llama3.2:1b: Shell has agreed to pay $1 million (approximately £522,000) to former finance chief Judy Boynton as part of a settlement with investors who were misled by the company's overstatement of its reserves.
Boynton left her position on December 31, 2004, and was paid out as part of an agreement with Shell.
llama3.2:3b: Shell pays $1m to former finance chief Judy Boynton, who left in December after being accused of failing to act on warning about over-stated reserves, which led to her company's investigation finding she shared responsibility.
gemma2:2b: Shell is paying $1 million to former finance chief Judy Boynton following her departure in 2004 after overstating its oil reserves.
The payout, in line with Boynton's contract, includes long-term share options while she forfeits a 2003 incentive plan due to unmet targets.
Shell was fined £82.7 million for violating market rules and investigated Ms Boynton for her role in the accounting error.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Shell is paying $1 million to Judy Boynton as a severance payment.
She left Shell in January 2004 after over-stating its reserve data, but she had agreed to stay by mutual agreement with Jeroen van der Veer to pursue other career opportunities.
The company's board found that she was responsible for the inflated reserves and failed to inquire further about them.
Shell restated its reserve data four times in 2003.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Former Shell finance chief Judy Boynton receives $1 million as a severance payment after her contract was extended by 4 months and she failed to meet performance targets, leading to restatements of company's reserve estimates.
The incident triggered a board reshuffle at the time.
qwen2.5:3b: Shell pays $1m to former finance chief Judy Boynton for overstating reserves in April 2004.
The payout was in line with her contract, though she could not collect on a previous incentive plan due to missed targets.
This led to the resignations of Shell's chairman Sir Phil Watts and production chief Walter van der Vijver.

An investigation found Boynton shared responsibility despite being informed by Van der Vijver that the company had "fooled" investors about its reserves, leading Shell to restate reserves four times in 2003.
In September, Shell faced fines of £82.7m from regulators on both sides of the Atlantic for violating market rules regarding its reserve reporting.
opencoder:1.5b: The payoff for former Shell boss was a $1 million payout at the company’s ex-finance chief who left with a severance agreement in place.
The company reported that it had made a "fooling" move about its reserve ratios, and after an investigation by investors, the chief shared responsibility for the company's behaviour.
Despite her efforts to make contact with regulators, she did not disclose further.
In all, Shell’s payoff at the end of 2003 was $82.7 million in fines.

tinyllama:1.1b: In a $1m (£522,000) payoff to Shell's former finance chief Judy Boynton after overstated its reserve, Ms Boynton finally leaves the company by mutual agreement.
The severance package includes 20% larger options and is paid in line with her contract, but she fails to collect on a 2003 incentive plan since the firm failed to meet the targets included in it.
The resignation of Sir Phil Watts and production chief Walter van der Vijver also led to an investigation commissioned by Shell.

tinydolphin:1.1b: Shell has to pay $1 million (£522,000) to Judy Boynton, who was the former finance chief, after it understated her company's reserves during a period in April 2004.
Boynton left the firm on December 31, 2003.
She spent the following year as a special advisor to Shell CEO Jeroen van der Veer.
Shell claimed it had overstated its reserves by 20%, but later announced that the total amount was actually 20% smaller than they had initially thought.
The severance package means she keeps long-term share options, but does not collect on a 2003 incentive plan since the company failed to meet the targets included in it.
Shell's chairman Sir Phil Watts and production chief Walter van der Vijver both resigned as a result of this alleged fraudulence.
The investigation commissioned by Shell found that Boynton had to share responsibility for the company's actions.
Despite receiving an email from Van de Vijver in which he stated that the firm had "foolishly" reported overstated reserves, the investigation said she did not act upon this information.
In all, Shell restated its reserves four times during 2003.
In September 2007, it paid a $82.7 million fine to regulators on both sides of the Atlantic for violating market rules in reporting their reserves.
